answer_html: We also note that Q(4) is the statement “17 is divisible by 3” whichis false.
answer_latex:
We also note that \emph{Q}(4) is the statement ``17 is
divisible by 3'' whichis false.
hints_html: You need to first determine whether the statement is true or false. How might you determine this? Is there some way to check specific cases?
hints_latex:

hints_raw: You need to first determine whether the statement is true or false. How might you determine this? Is there some way to check specific cases?
question: 2 (a)
sols_html:
We note that P(4) is the statement “4 is divisible by 4”, which is true. We also note that Q(4) is the statement “17 is divisible by 3” which is false. As such, the implication

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle P(4) \Rightarrow Q(4)\end{aligned}\]

does not hold, and so the statement

\[\begin{aligned} \forall\, n \in \mathbb{N}, P(n) \Rightarrow Q(n)\end{aligned}\]

is false.
sols_raw:
We note that ''P''(4) is the statement "4 is divisible by 4", which is true. We also note that ''Q''(4) is the statement "17 is divisible by 3" which is false. As such, the implication

:<math>\displaystyle
P(4) \Rightarrow Q(4)
</math>

does not hold, and so the statement

:<math>
\forall\, n \in \mathbb{N}, P(n) \Rightarrow Q(n)
</math>

is false.
statement_html:
For any natural number n, let P(n) be the statement “n is divisible by 4”, and let Q(n) be the statement “n2+1 is divisible by 3”.

Consider the statement

\[\begin{aligned} \forall\, n \in N, P(n) \Rightarrow Q(n)\end{aligned}\]

Is this statement true or false? Prove your answer.
statement_latex:
For any natural number \emph{n}, let \emph{P}(\emph{n}) be the statement
"\emph{n} is divisible by 4", and let \emph{Q}(\emph{n}) be the
statement "\emph{n}\textsuperscript{2}+1 is divisible by 3".

Consider the statement

\begin{align*}
\forall\, n \in N, P(n) \Rightarrow Q(n)
\end{align*}

Is this statement true or false? Prove your answer.
statement_raw:
For any natural number ''n'', let ''P''(''n'') be the statement "''n'' is divisible by 4", and let ''Q''(''n'') be the statement "''n''<sup>2</sup>+1 is divisible by 3".

Consider the statement

:<math>\forall\, n \in N, P(n) \Rightarrow Q(n)</math>

Is this statement true or false? Prove your answer.
